awd_abstract_narration:
Quantum mechanics is on the threshold of fundamentally changing modern technology in a number of areas, with new technologies emerging regularly. As these emerge, verification techniques are necessary to ensure confidence and reliability.  The primary objective of this project is to develop new ways of uncovering errors that occur in quantum systems, while using a minimum of assumptions about those systems. For example, in quantum communication involving quantum key sharing, it is important for the communications partners to be assured that they have successfully shared a secret key, when in fact they have not. The error detection scheme at the core of this project will let them detect this error, while making a minimum of assumptions about their apparatus. The experiments will advance the movement of quantum technologies from theoretical possibility to actual implementation. These experiments will be performed by undergraduate students, preparing them for scientific careers by exposing them to emerging fields of research and new technologies.

Two important operations performed in experiments characterizing quantum systems are (i) preparing systems in particular states and then (ii) performing measurements on those states. State preparation and measurement are usually independent, uncorrelated operations, and when analyzing data it is usually assumed that this is the case. However, if there are indeed correlations between the state preparations and the measurements, it is possible to draw erroneous conclusions from measured data. The primary objective of this project is to experimentally demonstrate a technique called loop state-preparation-and-measurement (SPAM) tomography, which is capable of detecting such correlated errors while making a minimum of assumptions. No assumptions need to be made about either the state preparation or the measurements, other than that the experimenter knows the Hilbert space dimension of the system they are working with. Experiments will be performed on one- and two-qubit systems, with the qubits encoded in the polarizations of individual photons. The group proposes to demonstrate that loop SPAM tomography is capable of detecting correlations between state preparations and measurements of single qubits. They also propose to detect nonlocal correlations between measurements of two qubits in which one party is attempting to fake a Bell inequality violation.

por.por_cntn:
Inherently quantum technologies are on the cusp of making a very large impact on society: from secure messaging systems that use quantum cryptography, to ultrafast computation using quantum computers, to precise timing and positioning using quantum metrology. However, in order to get to that future, we need better techniques for characterizing quantum systems--techniques that minimize our assumptions about the systems under study and that reduce errors. One such technique is state-preparation-and-measurement (SPAM) tomography, which simultaneously yields information about the state of a quantum system and the detectors that are used to perform measurements on that system. In particular, certain types of SPAM tomography can detect errors in the state preparations and/or the measurements.

The primary scientific objective of this project was to experimentally demonstrate SPAM tomography, and to explore its ability to provide information about quantum states and detectors in different situations. To meet this objective we performed experiments with quantum bits, or qubits, encoded in single photons and entangled-photon pairs.

We first demonstrated that SPAM tomography is capable of detecting errors between the state preparation and measurement of a single qubit, in a device-independent manner with a minimum of assumptions [1]. Next we demonstrated that SPAM tomography is capable of detecting errors between measurements performed on two spatially-separated qubits [2]. This experiment also demonstrated that SPAM tomography is capable of detecting a specific type of eavesdropper that is attempting to disrupt an entanglement-based quantum cryptography system. Both of these experiments demonstrated new techniques that physicists and engineers can use to verify that their quantum processors are working as expected, thus increasing our confidence in the reliability of quantum devices.

We also developed and demonstrated a technique for characterizing, in a self-consistent manner, both the unknown state of a quantum system and the detectors that perform measurements on that system [3]. This technique requires fewer measurements than other similar techniques, which provides an advantage for experimentalists, if only in the time needed to perform the measurements. The ability to do this may have an impact on characterizing devices used for quantum information processing applications.

Finally, we demonstrated that we can use a variation of SPAM tomography to detect errors in a recently developed type of quantum cryptography, called twin-field-quantum-key distribution (TFQKD) [4]. Because of its ability to transmit keys over very long distances, TFQKD promises to be a large part of the QKD landscape in the future. As such, the ability to detect errors in TFQKD will be important.

In addition to the scientific goals, another important goal of the project was the training of undergraduate students. A total of twelve students worked on aspects of the project, and five of them are members of groups that are under represented in physics. All but one of these students have gone on to careers in STEM, are attending graduate school in STEM fields, or are applying to STEM graduate programs.

[1]        A. F. McCormick, S. J. van Enk, and M. Beck, "Experimental Demonstration of Loop State-Preparation-and-Measurement Tomography," Phys. Rev. A 95, 042329 (2017).

[2]        M. E. Feldman et al., "Loop State-Preparation-and-Measurement Tomography of a Two-Qubit System," J. Opt. Soc. Am. B 35, 1811 (2018).

[3]        A. Stephens et al., "Self-Consistent State and Measurement Tomography with Fewer Measurements," Phys. Rev. A 104, 012416 (2021).

[4]        B. Panchumarthi, A. Stephens, and M. Beck, "Detecting Correlated Errors in Twin-Field Quantum Key Distribution," J. Opt. Soc. Am. B 40, 279 (2023).
